title: Rift Between Officers and Residents as Killings Persist in South Bronx - The New York Times
author: Benjamin Mueller and Al Baker
content: After the bullet shells get counted, the blood dries and the votive candles burn out, people peer down from   windows and see crime scenes gone cold: a band of yellow police tape blowing in the breeze. The South <Location>Bronx<Location>, just across the Harlem River from <Location>Manhattan<Location> and once shorthand for urban dysfunction, still suffers violence at levels long ago slashed in many other parts of <Location><Location>New York<Location> City<Location>. And yet the city’s efforts to fight it remain splintered, underfunded and burdened by scandal. In the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization>, at the southern tip of the <Location>Bronx<Location>, as in other poor, minority neighborhoods across the country, people long hounded for   infractions are crying out for more protection against grievous injury or death. By September, four of every five shootings in the precinct this year were unsolved. Out of the city’s 77 precincts, the 40th has the highest murder rate but the fewest detectives per violent crime, reflecting disparities in staffing that hit hardest in some neighborhoods outside <Location>Manhattan<Location>, according to a <Organization><Location>New York<Location> <Organization>Times<Organization><Organization> analysis of <Organization>Police Department<Organization> data. Investigators in the precinct are saddled with twice the number of cases the department recommends, even as their bosses are called to <Organization>Police Headquarters<Organization> to answer for the sharpest crime rise in the city this year. And across the <Location>Bronx<Location>, investigative resources are squeezed. It has the highest   rate of the city’s five boroughs but the thinnest detective staffing. Nine of the 14   precinct detective squads for violent crime in the city are there. The borough’s robbery squad is smaller than <Location>Manhattan<Location>’s, even though the <Location>Bronx<Location> has had 1, 300 more cases this year. And its homicide squad has one detective for every four murders, compared with one detective for roughly every two murders in Upper <Location>Manhattan<Location> and more than one detective per murder in Lower <Location>Manhattan<Location>. In   lobbies and   family apartments, outside methadone clinics and art studios, people take note of the inequity. They hear police commanders explain that they lack the resources to place a floodlight on a dangerous block or to post officers at a   corner. They watch witnesses cower behind   doors, more fearful of a gunman’s crew than confident in the <Organization>Police Department<Organization>’s ability to protect them. So though people see a lot, they rarely testify. And in the South <Location>Bronx<Location>, as in so many predominantly black and Hispanic neighborhoods like it in <Location>the United States<Location>, the contract between the police and the community is in tatters. Some people have stories of crime reports that were ignored, or 911 calls that went unanswered for hours. Others tell of a 911 call for help ending in the caller’s arrest, or of a minor charge leading to 12 hours in a fetid holding cell. This is the paradox of policing in the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization>. Its neighborhoods have historically been prime targets for aggressive tactics, like    that are designed to ward off disorder. But precinct detectives there have less time than anywhere else in the city to answer for the blood spilled in violent crimes. <Person>Gola White<Person>, who was beside her daughter when she was shot and killed in a playground this summer, four years after her son was gunned down in the same housing project, ticked off the public safety resources that she said were scant in <Location>Bronx<Location> neighborhoods like hers: security cameras, lights, locks, investigating police officers. “Here, we have nothing,” she said. When it comes to “  families,” she said, the authorities “don’t really care as much. That’s how I feel. ” The <Organization>Times<Organization> has been documenting the murders logged this year in the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization>, one of a handful of neighborhoods where deadly violence remains a problem in an era of   crime in <Location><Location>New York<Location> City<Location>. The homicides  —   14 in the precinct this year, up from nine in 2015  —   strain detectives, and when they go unsolved, as half of them have this year, some look to take the law into their own hands. From hundreds of conversations with grieving relatives and friends, witnesses and police officers, the social forces that flare into murder in a place like the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> become clearer: merciless gang codes, mental illness, drugs and long memories of feuds that simmered out of officers’ view. The reasons some murders will never be solved also emerge: paralyzing fear of retribution, victims carrying secrets to their graves and relentless casework that forces detectives to move on in hopes that a break will come later. Frustrations build on all sides. Detectives’ phones rarely ring with tips, and officers grow embittered with witnesses who will not cooperate. In the meantime, a victim’s friends conduct their own investigations, and talk of grabbing a stash gun from a wheel well or a mother’s apartment when they find their suspect. In the chasm between the police and the community, gangs and gun violence flourish. Parents try to protect their families from drug crews’ threats, and officers work to overcome the residue of years of mistrust and understaffing in communities where they still go racing from one 911 call to the next. The streets around St. Mary’s Park were the scene of two fatal shootings logged in the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> this year. Both are unsolved. <Person>James Fernandez<Person> heard talk of the murders through the door of his   apartment on East 146th Street in a     the Betances Houses. He lived at the end of a long hallway strewn with hypodermic needles, empty dope bags and discarded Hennessy bottles. A   young men who spoke of being in a subset of the <Organization>Bloods<Organization> gang had made it their drug market, slinging marijuana and cocaine to regulars, flashing firearms and blowing smoke into the Fernandez apartment. When Mr. Fernandez, 40, asked the young men to move, they answered by busting up his car. This kind of crime, an anachronism in much of <Location>New York<Location>, still rattles the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization>, even though murders there have fallen to 14 this year from 83 in 1991. It has more major felony crimes per resident than any other residential district in the city. It is also one of the poorest communities in the country, and many young men find their way into underground markets. Mr. Fernandez was not one to shrink from the threats. When he was growing up on the Lower East Side, he rode his bicycle around to the customers of the drug dealers he worked for and collected payments in a backpack. After leaving that life, he got a tech maintenance job and, three years ago, moved into the Betances Houses with his wife and daughter, now 11. He had two choices to get help with the drug crew: call the police for help and risk being labeled a snitch, or call his old Lower East Side bosses for muscle and risk violence. He chose the police. Again and again, he walked into a local substation, <Organization>Police Service Area 7<Organization>, and asked for protection. His daughter was using an inhaler to relieve coughs from the marijuana smoke. Mr. Fernandez and his wife got terrible headaches. “There’s a lot of killers here, and we are going to kill you,” a sergeant’s police report quoted a    telling Mr. Fernandez in August 2015. A second report filed the same day said a    warned him, “I’m going to shoot through your window. ” Mr. Fernandez told the police both the teenagers’ names, which appear in the reports, and then went home. He said one of their friends had seen him walk into the substation, and they tried to intimidate him out of filing another report. Three days later, the same    propped his bike on their door, “then said if I was to open the door and say something, they would body slam me,” Mr. Fernandez’s wife, <Person>Maria Fernandez<Person>, wrote on slips of paper she used to document the hallway ruckus and the inadequate police response. The boys made comments about how easy a target she was and about how they would have to “slap” her if she opened the door while they made a drug sale, and they threatened to beat the Fernandez family because “they are the ones snitching,” her notes say. But another   complaint at the substation, 10 days after the first, brought no relief. A week later, feeling desperate, Ms. Fernandez tried calling: first to the substation, at 8:50 p. m. when one of the boys blew weed smoke at her door and made a   threat to attack her, and then to 911 at 10:36 p. m. The police never came, she wrote in her notes. She tried the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> station house next, but officers at the desk left her standing in the public waiting area for a   she said, making her fear being seen again. Officers put her in worse danger some months later, she said, when they came to her door and announced in front of the teenagers that they were there on a complaint about drug activity. Mr. Fernandez started doing the work that he said the police had failed to do. He wired a camera into his peephole to record the drugs and guns. The footage hark back to the <Location>New York<Location> of the 1980s, still very much present to some of the precinct’s residents. Around 6:30 each morning, Sgt. <Person>Michael J. LoPuzzo<Person> walks through the tall wooden doors of the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> station house. The cases that land on his metal desk  —   dead bodies with no known cause, strip club brawls, shooting victims hobbling into the hospital themselves  —   bring resistance at every turn, reminding him of an earlier era in the city’s   campaign. “I haven’t got one single phone call that’s putting me in the right direction here,” said <Person>Sergeant LoPuzzo<Person>, the head of the precinct’s detective squad, one day this summer as he worked on an answer to an email inquiry from a murder victim’s aunt about why the killer had not been caught. “And people just don’t understand that. ” Often it is detectives who most feel the effects of people turning on the police. Witnesses shout them away from their doors just so neighbors know they refuse to talk. Of the 184 people who were shot and wounded in the <Location>Bronx<Location> through early September, more than a third  —   66 victims  —   refused to cooperate. Over the same period in the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization>, squad detectives closed three of 17 nonfatal shootings, and 72 of 343 robbery cases. Part of the resistance stems from   preventive policing tactics, like    that were a hallmark of the     style under former Mayor <Person>Michael R. Bloomberg<Person> and his police commissioner, <Person>Raymond W. Kelly<Person>. Near the height of the    strategy, in 2012, the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> had the   stops in the city, the   stops in which officers used force and the most frisks. Of 18, 276 stops that year, 15, 521 were of people who had done nothing criminal. The precinct was also one of the   areas that the department flooded with its newest officers. At roll calls, they were pressured to generate numbers: write tickets and make arrests. They had no choice but to give a summons to a young man playing in a park after dark, even if the officers had done the same growing up in the same neighborhood. “I need to bring something in today to justify my existence,” Officer <Person>Argenis Rosado<Person>, who joined the precinct in 2010, said in an interview at the station house. “So now you’re in a small area, and day after day you’re hammering the same community. Of course that community’s eventually going to turn on you. ” The pressure warped the way officers and residents saw each other. Rookies had to ignore why someone might be drinking outside or sitting on a stoop. “Some of the cops that came out at that time probably viewed the community differently, too,” said <Person>Hector Espada<Person>, a   veteran of the precinct. “Not because they wanted to, but because they had to. Because some way or somehow, you can’t give someone a $115 summons and feel like you guys could still have a civil conversation after that. ” <Person>Morale<Person> wilted in the aged station house on <Person>Alexander Avenue<Person>, in <Location>Mott Haven<Location>. Officers felt pressure to downgrade crime complaints to make them appear less serious. Several said in interviews that they had overlooked crime reports from immigrants because they were seen as unlikely to complain, and watched supervisors badger victims into repeating their stories in hopes that they would drop their complaints. The practice of downgrading complaints resulted in the disciplining of 19 officers in the precinct last year, one in a string of scandals that has left officers there feeling overscrutinized for problems that also existed elsewhere. Four commanders in the precinct were sent packing in five years, one of them after officers were found to be “ticket fixing,” or forgiving parking tickets for friends, and another after he was recorded giving guidance on whom to stop and frisk: black boys and men, ages 14 to 21. Some officers fled to other commands. Others became reluctant to take assignments in proactive policing units, like   that put them in   situations on the street. “Whenever I walked through the doors of the precinct, to me, it seemed like a black cloud,” said <Person>Russell Lewis<Person>, a    of the 40th. “It was like a heaviness. When you walked in, all you wanted to do was do your 8 hours 35 minutes and go home, because you didn’t want to get caught up in anything. ” The precinct covers only about two square miles, but the more than a dozen housing projects there mean that it overflows with people. Methadone clinics draw addicts from around the city.   lofts on the southern edge of the precinct presage a wave of gentrification. Even as the <Organization>Police Department<Organization> has hired 1, 300 more officers for neighborhood policing and counterterrorism, officers in the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> said they could still rush to 25 911 calls during a shift  —   a number unchanged from what the new police commissioner, <Person>James P. <Person>O’Neill<Person><Person>, said he was handling in a similar South <Location>Bronx<Location> precinct 15 years ago. Several dozen calls at a time can be waiting for a response. Residents know that if you want the police for a domestic problem, it helps to hint that there is a weapon. Last year, the precinct drew the   number of civilian complaints for officer misconduct in the city, and the most lawsuits stemming from police actions. The precinct is trying to improve morale under a new commanding officer, Deputy Inspector <Person>Brian Hennessy<Person>. A cadre of what the department calls neighborhood coordination officers has been on patrol since last January, part of a citywide effort under Mr. <Person>O’Neill<Person> and Mayor <Person>Bill de Blasio<Person> to bring back the beat cop, unencumbered by chasing every last 911 call, who can listen to people’s concerns and help with investigations. The precinct has made among the most gun arrests in the city, and officers said they now had more discretion to resolve encounters without a summons or an arrest. At one corner near a school, on Courtlandt Avenue and East 151st Street, that has long spawned complaints about gunfire and fights, Inspector Hennessy and some of his officers painted over graffiti and swept up drug paraphernalia this summer. People said it was the first answer to their complaints in years. But the inspector acknowledged that the residue of   policing lingers. “That perception really sticks,” he said. The workload in the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> is startling and reveals a gap in how detective squads are equipped to answer violent crime in <Location>Manhattan<Location> compared with the <Location>Bronx<Location>, <Location>Brooklyn<Location> and <Location>Queens<Location>. Three of the precinct’s 16 detectives are carrying more than 400 cases each this year, and many others have loads in the high 300s, even though the department advises 150 in violent precincts. When they are assigned a homicide, they typically have four days to investigate before dealing with other cases. Quieter precincts can give detectives a month with little distraction to investigate a murder. Detectives in the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> have each handled an average of 79 violent felonies this year through    —   murders, rapes, felony assaults and robberies. By contrast, a detective in the precinct on the southern end of Staten Island carries nine such cases a detective in the precinct patrolling Union Square and Gramercy Park handles 16 and a detective in the precinct for most of <Location>Washington Heights<Location> handles 32, the citywide median. Last year, the 40th was the    for violent crime, with 65 cases per detective. In the <Location>Bronx<Location> as a whole, a precinct detective has carried an average of 58 violent felonies this year, compared with 27 in <Location>Manhattan<Location>, 37 in <Location>Brooklyn<Location>, 38 in <Location>Queens<Location> and 25 on Staten Island. Rape cases and robbery patterns are later sent to more specialized units, but precinct detectives do extensive initial work to interview victims, write reports and process evidence. <Organization>Precinct<Organization>s in much of <Location>Manhattan<Location>, which are whiter and wealthier than the South <Location>Bronx<Location>, often have more property felonies, like stolen laptops or credit cards, and the police say those can be complex. But even accounting for those crimes, the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> has some of the heaviest caseloads of overall crime per detective in the city. <Person>Michael Palladino<Person>, the head of <Organization>the Detectives’ Endowment Association<Organization> and a former <Location>Bronx<Location> officer, said staffing disparities affected the department’s efforts to build trust in communities like the South <Location>Bronx<Location>. Witnesses make a calculation, he said: “If I cooperate with the detectives, there’s so much work, there’s so few of them there, they won’t even get the chance to protect me, or they’ll be there too late when the retaliation comes. ” <Person>Sergeant LoPuzzo<Person>, who turned down a more prestigious post to stay in the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization>, said that his squad worked tirelessly to handle cases with the people he had, and that while every squad wanted more detectives, staffing needs for counterterrorism units and task forces had created new deployment challenges across the department. “We fight with the army we have, not the army we wish we had,” he said. Details of how the <Organization>Police Department<Organization> assigns its 36, 000 officers are closely held and constantly in <Location>flux<Location>, and the public has minimal information on how personnel are allocated. Presented with The <Organization>Times<Organization>’s analysis of confidential staffing data, the department’s chief of detectives, <Person>Robert K. <Person>Boyce<Person><Person>, vowed to send more detectives to the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> and said the department would reassess its deployment more broadly in troubled precincts. He said a recent decision to bring gang, narcotics and vice detectives under his command made it easier to shift personnel. Chief <Person>Boyce<Person> said the burdens on detectives went beyond felony crimes to include   and   cases. And he noted the support that precinct squads got from centralized units focusing on robberies, gangs or grand larcenies, for example. Major crime keeps pounding the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization>, at rates that in 2015 were only a tenth of a percent lower than in 2001, even as citywide crime dropped by more than a third over the same period. But the precinct’s detective squad shrank by about eight investigators during those years, according to staffing data obtained from <Organization>the City Council<Organization> through a Freedom of Information Law request. The squad covering Union Square and Gramercy Park, where crime dropped by a third over that period, grew by about 11 investigators. (The 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> was given an additional detective and four   investigators this summer, when it was already missing three detectives for illness or other reasons.) Retired detectives are skeptical that community relations alone can drive down crime in the city’s last “” the busiest precincts. Rather, they say, the <Organization>Police Department<Organization> should be dedicating more resources to providing the same sort of robust investigative response that seems standard in <Location>Manhattan<Location>. “Any crime in <Location>Manhattan<Location> has to be solved,” said <Person>Howard Landesberg<Person>, who was a 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> detective in the late 1980s. “The outer boroughs are, like, forgotten. ” Retired detectives said that understaffing made it harder to solve crimes in the <Location>Bronx<Location>, <Location>Brooklyn<Location> and <Location>Queens<Location>, where the higher prevalence of gang and drug killings already saddled investigators with cases in which people were not inclined to cooperate. Through   detectives had closed 67 percent of homicides in <Location>Manhattan<Location> and 76 percent of those in Staten Island this year, compared with 54 percent of those in the <Location>Bronx<Location>, 42 percent of those in <Location>Queens<Location> and 31 percent of those in <Location>Brooklyn<Location>. Of last year’s homicides, detectives cleared 71 percent in <Location>Manhattan<Location>, 63 percent in the <Location>Bronx<Location>, 62 percent in <Location>Queens<Location>, 57 percent in Staten Island and 31 percent in <Location>Brooklyn<Location>. “It’s the culture of the <Organization>Police Department<Organization> that they worry about <Location>Manhattan<Location>,” said <Person>Joseph L. Giacalone<Person>, a former sergeant in the <Location>Bronx<Location> Cold Case Squad, in part “because that’s where the money is. ” He added: “When de Blasio came in, he talked about the tale of two cities. And then he’s done the complete opposite of what he said. It’s just business as usual. ” The <Location>Bronx<Location>’s struggles extend into prosecutions. In each of the last five years, prosecutors in the <Location>Bronx<Location> have declined to prosecute violent felony cases more than anywhere else in the city. And the rate of conviction in the <Location>Bronx<Location> is routinely the lowest in the city as well, but has ticked up this year to surpass <Location>Brooklyn<Location>’s rate through November as <Location>Bronx<Location> prosecutors work to streamline cases. Some cases have become even more difficult to win because of the   problem in the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization>, which has allowed defense lawyers to attack the credibility of officers who were implicated, said <Organization>Patrice O’Shaughnessy<Organization>, a spokeswoman for the <Location>Bronx<Location> District Attorney’s office. The district attorney, <Organization>Darcel D. Clark<Organization>, elected in 2015, said in a statement, “I was a judge here in the <Location>Bronx<Location>, and I heard from jurors that they can’t be impartial because they don’t trust the police. ” Against that tide of mistrust, <Person>Sergeant LoPuzzo<Person>’s detectives work 36 hours straight on some fresh cases. They buy Chinese takeout with their own money for a murder suspect. They carry surveillance videos home in hopes that their personal computers may enhance them better than a squad computer. They buy an urn for a homeless mother who has her murdered son’s ashes in a box. In the months after a killing, they can seem like the only people in this glittering city who are paying attention to the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization>’s homicide victims. Newly fatherless children go back to school without a therapist’s help. Victims’ families wander confused through a courthouse and nearly miss an appearance. Newspapers largely ignore killings of people with criminal pasts, pushing them down the priority lists of the   chiefs at <Organization>Police Headquarters<Organization>. In a stuffy   squad room, the detectives of the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> grapple with an inheritance of government neglect. They meet mothers who believe their sons might never have been murdered had a city guidance counselor listened to pleas to help them stay enrolled, or had a city housing worker fixed the locks or lights on a building. And the detectives work alongside a vicious system on the streets for punishing police cooperators. Young men scan court paperwork in prison, looking for the names of people who turned on them. One murder victim in the precinct this year was cast out of his crew after he avoided being arrested with them in a gang takedown some believed he was cooperating. A longtime 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> detective, <Person>Jeff Meenagh<Person>, said a witness in a homicide case was going to testify until he went back to his neighborhood and was told that anyone who testified would “get what you deserve. ” The allies <Person>Sergeant LoPuzzo<Person> makes are friendly only for so long. He helped clear a woman’s son of a robbery charge by locating surveillance video that proved he was not the robber. The mother started calling with tips under a code name  —   about a gun under a car, for example. But she always refused to testify. And she cut ties this year after <Person>Sergeant LoPuzzo<Person> arrested her son in the stabbing of two people and her   in a shooting. <Location><Location>New York<Location> City<Location> owns East 146th Street and the   buildings on each side. But <Person>James Fernandez<Person>, in the Betances Houses, said the reality on the ground was different: The drug boss ran the block. By October, Mr. Fernandez was increasingly afraid  —   and fed up. Mr. Fernandez and his wife went so far as to give officers keys to the building door, so they could get in whenever they wanted, showed them the videos and offered them   access to his camera so they could see what was happening in the hallway. A couple of officers said they needed a supervisor’s permission to do more. Others answered that the young men were only making threats. Officers occasionally stopped outside their building, causing the young men to scatter, but did not come inside, Mr. Fernandez said. The menacing worsened. Mr. Fernandez’s daughter was harassed as she arrived home from school. She grew more and more distressed, and her parents had her start seeing a therapist. Mr. Fernandez made several complaints at the office of the borough president, <Person>Ruben Diaz Jr.<Person> and visited a victim’s advocate in the district attorney’s office. On Oct. 20, 2015, he sent an online note to the police commissioner’s office. “We went to all proper channels for help,” the note said. “Both precincts failed us, except 2 officers who helped us, but their hands are tied. No one else to turn to. I have months of video of multiple crimes taking place and we are in extreme danger. ” “40th and PSA 7 won’t do anything,” he wrote, referring to the local substation. “Please we need to speak to some one with authority. ” The local substation commander, Deputy Inspector <Person>Jerry <Person>O’Sullivan<Person><Person>, and the <Location>Bronx<Location> narcotics unit were alerted to the complaints. But Mr. Fernandez said he never heard from them. So he relied on his own street instincts to protect his family. He made pleas to a man he thought was employing the dealers in the hallway. The activity quieted briefly, but it returned after the young men rented a room in a woman’s apartment upstairs. Mr. Fernandez approached a different man who he learned was the boss of the operation. The man agreed to ask the dealers to calm down. He even hired a drug customer to sweep the hallway, Mr. Fernandez said. But two weeks later, the dealing and the harassment resumed. So he went to his old Lower East Side bosses, who hired men to trail his wife and daughter on their way out of the building and make sure they made it safely to school. At other times they sat outside the Betances Houses. He also bought two bulletproof vests, for about $700 each. He could not find one small enough for his daughter. “I have no faith in the City of <Location>New York<Location>, I have no faith in the police, I have no faith in the politicians,” Mr. Fernandez said. “The only thing I know for sure: God, if we’re in a situation again, I will be left to defend my family. ” Paying such close attention to what was happening in the hallway, Mr. Fernandez said he learned some details about two recent homicides that the 40th <Organization>Precinct<Organization> was investigating. But because his calls for help were going nowhere, he said he decided not to put himself in greater risk by talking: He would not tell the police what he had learned. “I’m bending over backward, and nobody’s not even doing anything,” he said. “Why am I going to help you, if you ain’t going to help me?” By last January, a new neighborhood coordination officer was working with residents of the Betances Houses, and ended up with the most arrests in his housing command, Inspector <Person>O’Sullivan<Person> said. Chief <Person>Boyce<Person> said that the silos in which gang and narcotics detectives used to work made responding to complaints more difficult, but that the recent restructuring would remove those obstacles. “No one should live like Mr. Fernandez lived, with people dealing drugs outside of his apartment,” he said. Mr. Fernandez’s complaints did not spur any arrests, but two men from the hallway were caught separately this year in shootings. One of them, whom Mr. Fernandez named in a police report, was charged this summer with hitting an officer with a metal folding chair and firing three gunshots into a crowd, court papers say. He is being held on Rikers Island on an attempted murder charge. That was too late for Mr. Fernandez. By May, he had moved his family away.

title: Tyrus Wong, ‘Bambi’ Artist Thwarted by Racial Bias, Dies at 106 - The New York Times
author: Margalit Fox
content: When <Person>Walt <Organization>Disney<Organization><Person>’s “Bambi” opened in 1942, critics praised its spare, haunting visual style, vastly different from anything <Organization>Disney<Organization> had done before. But what they did not know was that the film’s striking appearance had been created by a Chinese immigrant artist, who took as his inspiration the landscape paintings of the Song dynasty. The extent of his contribution to “Bambi,” which remains a   mark for film animation, would not be widely known for decades. Like the film’s title character, the artist, <Person>Tyrus <Person>Wong<Person><Person>, weathered irrevocable separation from his mother  —   and, in the hope of making a life in <Location>America<Location>, incarceration, isolation and rigorous interrogation  —   all when he was still a child. In the years that followed, he endured poverty, discrimination and chronic lack of recognition, not only for his work at <Organization>Disney<Organization> but also for his fine art, before finding acclaim in his 90s. Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> died on Friday at 106. A <Location>Hollywood<Location> studio artist, painter, printmaker, calligrapher,   illustrator and, in later years, maker of fantastical kites, he was one of the most celebrated   artists of the 20th century. But because of the marginalization to which   were long subject, he passed much of his career unknown to the general public. Artistic recognition, when Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> did find it, was all the more noteworthy for the fact that among Chinese immigrant men of his generation, professional prospects were largely limited to menial jobs like houseboy and laundryman. Trained as a painter, Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> was a leading figure in the Modernist movement that flourished in <Location>California<Location> between the first and second World Wars. In 1932 and again in 1934, his work was included in group shows at <Organization>the Art Institute of Chicago<Organization> that also featured <Person>Picasso<Person>, <Person>Matisse<Person> and <Person>Paul Klee<Person>. As a staff artist for <Location>Hollywood<Location> studios from the 1930s to the 1960s, he drew storyboards and made vibrant paintings, as detailed as any architectural illustrations, that helped the director envision each scene before it was shot. Over the years his work informed the look of animated pictures for <Organization>Disney<Organization> and   films for <Organization>Warner Brothers<Organization> and other studios, among them “The Sands of Iwo Jima” (1949) “Rebel Without a Cause” (1955) and “The Wild Bunch” (1969). But of the dozens of films on which he worked, it was for “Bambi” that Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> was  —   belatedly  —   most renowned. “He was truly involved with every phase of production,” <Person>John <Person>Canemaker<Person><Person>, an   animator and a historian of animation at <Organization>New York University<Organization>, said in an interview for this obituary in March. “He created an art direction that had really never been seen before in animation. ” In 2013 and 2014, Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> was the subject of “Water to Paper, Paint to Sky,” a major retrospective at the <Organization>Disney<Organization> Family Museum in <Location>San Francisco<Location>. From the museum’s windows, which overlook <Location>San Francisco<Location> Bay, he could contemplate Angel Island, where more than nine decades earlier, as a lone    he had sought to gain admission to a country that adamantly did not want him. <Person>Wong<Person> <Person>Gen Yeo<Person> (the name is sometimes Romanized <Person>Wong<Person> Gaing Yoo) was born on Oct. 25, 1910, in a farming village in <Location>Guangdong Province<Location>. As a young child, he already exhibited a love of drawing and was encouraged by his father. In 1920, seeking better economic prospects, <Person>Gen Yeo<Person> and his father embarked for <Location>the <Location>United States<Location><Location>, leaving his mother and sister behind. <Person>Gen Yeo<Person> would never see his mother again. They were obliged to travel under false identities  —   a state of affairs known among Chinese immigrants as being a “paper son”  —   in the hope of circumventing the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882. Signed into law by President <Person>Chester A. Arthur<Person>, the act, which drastically curtailed the number of Chinese people allowed to enter the country, was among the earliest <Location>United States<Location> laws to impose severe restrictions on immigration. But in 1906, an unforeseen loophole opened in the form of the <Location>San Francisco<Location> earthquake and fire. Because a huge number of municipal documents, including birth and immigration records, were destroyed, many newly arrived Chinese capitalized on the loss, maintaining that they had been born in <Location>San Francisco<Location> before the fire. As <Location>United States<Location> citizens, they were entitled to bring over their relatives  —   or, in the case of <Person>Gen Yeo<Person> and his father, “paper sons” posing as relatives. Attuned to the deception, <Location>United States<Location> immigration officials put Chinese arrivals through a formidable inquisition to ensure they were who they claimed to be. The questions came like gunfire: In which direction does your village face? How many windows are in your house? Where in the house is the rice bin? How wide is your well? How deep? Are there trees in your village? Are there lakes? What shops can you name? The sponsoring relative was interrogated separately, and the answers had to match. For the new arrival, a major mistake, or a series of smaller ones, could mean deportation. To stand a chance of passing, aspirants memorized rigorous dossiers known as coaching papers. The ensuing interrogation was hard enough for adults.    <Person>Gen Yeo<Person> would undergo it alone. On Dec. 30, 1920, after a month at sea, the <Person>Wong<Person>s landed at Angel Island Immigration Station. The elder Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> was traveling as a merchant named Look Get his son as <Person>Look Tai Yow<Person>. “Angel Island is considered to be the Ellis Island of the West Coast,” Lisa <Person>See<Person>, the author of “On Gold Mountain” (1995) a nonfiction chronicle of her   family, said in an interview in 2016. However, she continued: “The goal was really very different than Ellis Island, which was supposed to be so welcoming. Angel Island opened very specifically to keep the Chinese out. ” Because Mr. <Person>Wong<Person>’s father had previously lived in <Location>the <Location>United States<Location><Location> as Look Get, he was able to clear Immigration quickly. But as a new arrival, <Person>Gen Yeo<Person> was detained on the island for nearly a month, the only child among the immigrants being held there. “I was scared half to death I just cried,” Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> recalled in “Tyrus,” an   documentary directed by <Person>Pamela <Person>Tom<Person><Person>, which premiered in 2015. “Every day is just miserable  —   miserable. I hated that place. ” On Jan. 27, 1921, in the presence of an interpreter and a stenographer, young <Person>Gen Yeo<Person>, posing as <Person>Look Tai Yow<Person>, was interrogated by three inspectors. His father had already been questioned. <Person>Gen Yeo<Person> was well prepared and answered without error. In <Location>Sacramento<Location>, where he joined his father, a schoolteacher <Location>America<Location>nized “Tai Yow” to “Tyrus,” and he was known as <Person>Tyrus <Person>Wong<Person><Person> ever after. Soon afterward, father and son were separated once more, when the elder Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> moved to <Location>Los Angeles<Location> to seek work. For reasons that have been lost to time, he could not take his son. Tyrus lived on his own in a <Location>Sacramento<Location> boardinghouse while attending elementary school. Two years later  —   possibly more  —   Tyrus traveled to <Location>Los Angeles<Location> to join his father, who had found work in a gambling den. They lived in a   boardinghouse sandwiched between a butcher shop and a brothel. After school, Tyrus worked as a houseboy for two <Location>Pasadena<Location> families, earning 50 cents a day. His first art teacher was his father, who trained him nightly in calligraphy by having him dip a brush in water and trace ghostly characters on newspaper: They could not afford ink or drawing paper. When Tyrus was in junior high, a teacher, noting his drawing talent, arranged a summer scholarship to <Organization>the <Organization>Otis<Organization> Art Institute<Organization> in <Location>Los Angeles<Location>. By his own account an indifferent student in public school, Tyrus found his calling at the institute, now <Organization>the <Organization>Otis<Organization> College of Art and Design<Organization>. When his scholarship ended he declined to return to junior high. His father scraped together the $90 tuition  —   a small fortune  —   to let him stay on as <Organization>Otis<Organization>’s youngest student. He studied there for at least five years, simultaneously working as the school janitor, before graduating in the 1930s. Not long afterward his father died, leaving young Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> entirely on his own. From 1936 to 1938, Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> was an artist for <Organization>the Works Progress Administration<Organization>, creating paintings for libraries and other public spaces. With friends, including the   artist <Person>Benji <Person>Okubo<Person><Person>, he founded the <Organization>Oriental Artists’ Group<Organization> of <Location>Los Angeles<Location>, which organized exhibitions of members’ work  —   an   level of exposure for Asian artists at the time. Mr. <Person>Wong<Person>, newly married and needing steady work, joined <Organization>Disney<Organization> in 1938 as an “” creating the thousands of intermediate drawings that bring animated sequences to life. Asians were then a novelty at <Location>Hollywood<Location> studios, and Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> was made keenly aware of the fact, first at <Organization>Disney<Organization> and later at <Organization>Warner Brothers<Organization>. One   flung a racial epithet at him. Another assumed on sight that he worked in the company cafeteria. Then there was the affront of the  ’s job itself: Painstaking, repetitive and for Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> quickly   it is the   work of animation  —   “a terrible use of his talents as a landscape artist and a painter,” Mr. <Person>Canemaker<Person> said. A reprieve came in the late 1930s, when Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> learned that <Organization>Disney<Organization> was adapting “Bambi, a Life in the Woods,” the 1923 novel by the Austrian writer <Person>Felix<Person> Salten about a fawn whose mother is killed by a hunter. In trying to animate the book, <Organization>Disney<Organization> had reached an impasse. The studio had enjoyed great success in 1937 with its animated film “Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,” a baroque production in which every detail of the backgrounds  —   every petal on every flower, every leaf on every tree  —   was meticulously represented. In an attempt to use a similar style for “Bambi,” it found that the ornate backgrounds camouflaged the deer and other forest creatures on which the narrative centered. Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> spied his chance. “I said, ‘<Person>Gee<Person>, this is all outdoor scenery,’” he recalled in a video interview years afterward, adding: “I said, ‘<Person>Gee<Person>, I’m a landscape painter! ’” Invoking the exquisite landscape paintings of the Song dynasty (<Person>A. D. 960<Person> —  1279) he rendered in watercolors and pastels a series of nature scenes that were moody, lyrical and atmospheric  —   at once lush and spare  —   with backgrounds subtly suggested by a stroke or two of the brush. “<Person>Walt <Organization>Disney<Organization><Person> went crazy over them,” said Mr. <Person>Canemaker<Person>, who wrote about Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> in his book “Before the Animation Begins: The Art and Lives of <Organization>Disney<Organization> Inspirational Sketch Artists” (1996). “He said, ‘I love this indefinite quality, the mysterious quality of the forest. ’” Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> was unofficially promoted to the rank of inspirational sketch artist. “But he was more than that,” Mr. <Person>Canemaker<Person> explained. “He was the designer he was the person they went to when they had questions about the color, about how to lay something out. He even influenced the music and the special effects: Just by the look of the drawings, he inspired people. ” Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> spent two years painting the illustrations that would inform every aspect of “Bambi. ” Throughout the finished film  —   lent a brooding quality by its stark landscapes misty, desaturated palette and figures often seen in silhouette  —   his influence is unmistakable. But in 1941, in the wake of a bitter employees’ strike that year, <Organization>Disney<Organization> fired Mr. <Person>Wong<Person>. Though he had chosen not to strike  —   he felt the studio had been good to him, Mr. <Person>Canemaker<Person> said  —   he was let go amid the lingering climate of   resentments. On “Bambi,” Mr. <Person>Wong<Person>’s name appears, quite far down in the credits, as a mere “background” artist. Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> joined <Organization>Warner Brothers<Organization> in 1942, working there  —   and lent out on occasion to other studios  —   until his retirement in 1968. The indignities he endured were not confined to the studios. Trying to buy a house, he and his wife, the former <Person>Ruth Kim<Person>, were told that each property they inquired about had just been sold. “Then in a month you’d go back there and the sign was still there,” Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> recalled in “Tyrus. ” After the Japanese attack on <Person>Pearl Harbor<Person> in December 1941, Mr. <Person>Wong<Person>, like many   took to wearing a lapel button proclaiming his heritage, lest an angry <Location>America<Location>n beat him up on the street. The war permanently dispersed the fledgling <Organization>Oriental Artists’ Group<Organization>. Mr. <Person>Wong<Person>’s friend Mr. <Person>Okubo<Person> was sent, with tens of thousands of other   to an internment camp. “If World War II hadn’t happened when it did, I think these artists, even the   artists, would have more of a name than they do today,” Ms. <Person>See<Person> said. “And that’s because this little movement that had just barely started was split apart by the war. ” Mr. <Person>Wong<Person>, who became a <Location>United States<Location> citizen in 1946, also designed Christmas cards for <Location>Hallmark<Location> and painted elegant   designs on dinnerware, now sought after by collectors. A longtime resident of <Location>Sunland<Location>, <Location>Calif.<Location> he became, in retirement, a renowned kitemaker, designing, building and hand coloring astonishing, airworthy creations  —   butterflies, swallows, whole flocks of owls, centipedes more than 100 feet long  —   that streaked the Southern <Location>California<Location> sky like paint on blue canvas. During the last 15 years of Ruth <Person>Wong<Person>’s life, when she was ill with dementia, Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> forsook his work to care for her. After her death in 1995, he slowly began making art again. In 2001, in formal recognition of his influence on “Bambi,” Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> was named a <Organization>Disney<Organization> Legend. The honor  —   whose previous recipients include <Person>Fred MacMurray<Person>, <Person>Julie Andrews<Person> and <Person>Annette Funicello  <Person>—   is bestowed by the <Person>Walt <Organization>Disney<Organization><Person> Company for outstanding contributions. In 2003, a retrospective of his work, curated in part by Ms. <Person>See<Person>, was the inaugural exhibition at the Chinese <Location>America<Location>n Museum in <Location>Los Angeles<Location>. The <Organization>Disney<Organization> Family Museum’s retrospective, “Water to Paper, Paint to Sky,” traveled in 2015 to <Organization>the Museum of Chinese<Organization> in <Location>America<Location>, in Lower <Location>Manhattan<Location>. Mr. <Person>Wong<Person>’s death, at his home in <Location>Sunland<Location>, was confirmed by the filmmaker Ms. <Person>Tom<Person>. His survivors include three daughters, <Person>Kay Fong<Person>,   <Person>Wong<Person> and Kim <Person>Wong<Person> and two grandchildren. When his daughters were small, Mr. <Person>Wong<Person> encouraged them to make art, as his father had encouraged him. Yet he would not let them have coloring books. The reason was simple: He did not want his children constrained, he said, by lines laid down by others.

title: Among Deaths in 2016, a Heavy Toll in Pop Music - The New York Times
author: William McDonald
content: Death may be the great equalizer, but it isn’t necessarily evenhanded. Of all the fields of endeavor that suffered mortal losses in 2016  —   consider <Person>Muhammad <Person>Ali<Person><Person> and <Person>Arnold Palmer<Person> in sports and the      <Location>Hollywood<Location> deaths of <Person>Carrie <Person>Fisher<Person><Person> and <Person>Debbie <Person>Reynolds<Person>  <Person>—   the pop music world had, hands down, the bleakest year. Start with <Person>David Bowie<Person>, whose stage persona  —   androgynous <Person>glam rocker<Person>, dance pop star, electronic experimentalist  —   was as   as his music. The year was only days old when the news came that he had died of cancer at 69. He had hinted that his time was short in the lyrics of his final album, released just two days before his death, but he had otherwise gone to great lengths to hide his illness from the public, a wish for privacy that ensured that his death would appear to have come out of the blue. Then came another shock, about three months later, when Prince accidentally overdosed on a painkiller and collapsed in an elevator at his sprawling home studio near <Location>Minneapolis<Location>. Death came to him at 57, and by all indications no one, including <Person>Prince Rogers Nelson<Person>, had seen it coming. As energetic onstage as ever, holding to an otherwise healthy regimen, he had successfully defied age into his sixth decade, so why not death, too? <Person>Leonard Cohen<Person>, on the other hand, in his 83rd year, undoubtedly did see it coming, just over his shoulder, but he went on his  —   I hesitate to say <Person>merry  <Person>—   way, ever the wise,   troubadour playing to sellout crowds and shrugging at the inevitable, knowing that the dark would finally overtake him but saying essentially, “Until then, here’s another song. ” It was as if 2016 hadn’t delivered enough jolts to the system when it closed out the year with yet another   death. <Person><Person>George<Person> Michael<Person>, the 1980s sensation whose <Organization>aura<Organization> had dimmed in later years, was 53 when he went to bed and never woke up on Christmas. Pop music figures fell all year, many of their voices still embedded in the nicked vinyl grooves of old records that a lot of people can’t bear to throw out. The roster included <Person><Person>Paul<Person> Kantner<Person> of <Person>Jefferson Airplane Keith <Location>Emerson<Location><Person> and <Person>Greg Lake<Person> of <Location>Emerson<Location>, Lake and <Person>Palmer Glenn Frey<Person> of the Eagles and <Person>Maurice White<Person> of Earth, Wind  Fire. <Person>Leon <Person>Russell<Person><Person>, the piano pounder with a <Organization>Delta<Organization> blues wail and a mountain man’s mass of hair, died. So did <Person>Merle Haggard<Person>, rugged country poet of the common man and the   outlaw. He was joined by the bluegrass legend <Person>Ralph Stanley<Person> and the guitar virtuoso who was practically glued to <Person>Elvis’s<Person> swiveling hips in the early days: <Person>Scotty Moore<Person>. And then there was <Person><Person>George<Person> Martin<Person>, whose   genius had such a creative influence on the sounds of <Person>John<Person>, <Person>Paul<Person>, <Person>George<Person> and <Person>Ringo<Person> (and, by extension, on the entire rock era) that he was hailed as the fifth Beatle. If the music stars could fill arenas, so could idols of another stripe: the mighty athletes who left the scene. No figure among them was as towering as <Person>Ali<Person>. Some called him the greatest sports figure of the 20th century, the boxer who combined power, grace and brains in a way the ring had never seen. But he was more than a great athlete. Matters of war, race and religion coursed through his life in a publicly turbulent way. Some people hated him when he refused to be drafted during the Vietnam War, a decision that cost him his heavyweight title. But more people admired him, even loved him, for his principled stands, his high spirits, his lightning mind, his winking   and, yes, his rhyming motormouth. Until illness closed in, little could contain him, certainly not mere ropes around a ring. Palmer, too, was transformational, golf’s first media star. The gentleman’s game was never quite the same after he began gathering an army on the rolling greenswards and leading a charge, his shirt coming untucked, a cigarette dangling from his lips, his club just that, a weapon, as he pressed the attack. An entire generation of   postwar guys took up the game because of Arnie, and not a few women did, too. He was athletically blessed, magnetically cool, telegenically handsome  —   but he was somehow one of them, too. The same was said of <Person>Gordie Howe<Person>, Mr. <Person>Hockey<Person>, a son of the <Location>Saskatchewan<Location> prairie who tore up the National <Person>Hockey<Person> League, hung up his skates at 52 and died at 88 and of <Person>Ralph Branca<Person>, a trolley car conductor’s son who was a living reminder that one crushing mistake  —   his, the fastball to <Person>Bobby Thomson<Person> that decided the 1951 <Organization>National League<Organization> pennant  —   can sometimes never be lived down. <Person>Pat Summitt<Person>, the coach who elevated women’s basketball, led her <Location>Tennessee<Location> teams to eight championships and won more games than any other college coach, could not defeat Alzheimer’s disease, dying at 64. And within months <Organization>the National Basketball Association<Organization> lost two giants from different eras. <Person>Clyde Lovelette<Person>, an <Location>Olympic<Location>, college and <Person>N. B. A. champion<Person> who transformed the game as one of its first truly big men, was 86 his hardwood heir <Person>Nate Thurmond<Person>, a defensive stalwart who battled <Person>Russell<Person>, <Person>Wilt<Person> and <Organization>Kareem<Organization> in the paint in a   <Organization>Hall of Fame<Organization> career, was 74. Even older, in the baseball ranks, was <Person>Monte Irvin<Person>. When he died at 96, there were few people still around who could remember watching him play, particularly in his prime, in the 1940s, when he was a star on the <Location>Negro<Location> circuit but barred from the   major leagues. He made the <Organization>Hall of Fame<Organization> anyway as a <Location><Location>New York<Location> Giant<Location> and became <Organization>Major League Baseball’s<Organization> first black executive, but when he died, fans pondered again the question that has hung over many an athletic career shackled by discrimination: What if? A different question, in an entirely different sphere, arose after the stunning news that Justice <Person>Antonin Scalia<Person> had died on a hunting trip in <Location>Texas<Location>: What now? In the thick of one of the most consequential <Organization>Supreme Court<Organization> careers of modern times, he left a void in conservative jurisprudence and, more urgently, a vacancy on the bench that has yet to be filled, raising still more questions about what may await the country. Other exits from the public stage returned us to the past. <Person>Nancy Reagan<Person>’s death evoked the 1980s <Organization>White House<Organization>, where   glamour and   West Coast conservatism took up residence on the banks of the <Location>Potomac<Location>. <Person>John<Person> Glenn’s had us thinking again about a   burst of national pride soaring into outer space. The deaths of <Person>Tom Hayden<Person> and <Person>Daniel Berrigan<Person>, avatars of defiance, harked back to the student rebellions of the 1960s and the Vietnam War’s roiling home front. <Person>Phyllis Schlafly<Person>’s obituaries were windows on the roots of the right wing’s ascension in American politics. The death of <Person>Janet Reno<Person>, the first woman to serve as attorney general, recalled the <Person>Clinton<Person> years, all eight of them, from the firestorm at <Location>Waco<Location>, <Location>Tex.<Location> to the international tug of war over a Cuban boy named <Person>Elián González<Person>, to the bitter <Organization>Senate<Organization> battle over impeachment. On other shores, <Person>Fidel Castro<Person>’s death at 90 summoned memories of Cuban revolution, nuclear brinkmanship and enduring enmity between a   strongman and the superpower only 90 miles away. The name of <Location>Boutros<Location>   the Egyptian diplomat who led <Organization>the United Nations<Organization>, led to replayed nightmares of genocide in <Location>Rwanda<Location> and <Location>Bosnia<Location>. The death of <Person>Shimon Peres<Person> removed a last link to the very founding of <Location>Israel<Location> and conjured decades of growing military power and fitful strivings for peace. And that of <Person>Elie Wiesel<Person>, in <Location>New York<Location>, after his tireless struggle to compel the world never to forget, made us confront once again the gas chambers of <Organization>Auschwitz<Organization>. If writers, too, are   even in fiction, then the world is poorer without the literary voices of <Person>Harper Lee<Person>, <Person>Umberto Eco<Person>, <Person>Pat Conroy<Person>, <Person>Jim Harrison<Person>, <Person>Anita Brookner<Person>, <Person>Alvin Toffler<Person>, <Person>Gloria Naylor<Person> and <Person>William Trevor<Person>, not to mention the playwrights <Person>Peter Shaffer<Person>, <Person>Dario Fo<Person> and,   <Person>Edward Albee  <Person>—   all dead in 2016. But just as treasured were those who spun   for our viewing pleasure  —   none more lustily than Ms. <Person>Fisher<Person>, the     Princess <Person>Leia<Person> of the “Star Wars” tales. Just a day later, capping a year of startling deaths, Ms. <Person>Reynolds<Person>, a singing and acting leading lady of an earlier era, died at 84 in the throes of a mother’s grief. Devotees of the “Harry Potter” movies were saddened by the death of <Person>Alan Rickman<Person>, who played the deliciously dour professor <Person>Severus <Organization>Snape<Organization><Person> in that blockbuster franchise but whose career, on both stage and screen, was far richer than many of <Organization>Snape<Organization>’s younger fans may have known. <Person>Zsa Zsa Gabor’s<Person> celebrity, by contrast, outshone a modest acting career. <Person>Gene Wilder<Person> and <Person>Garry Shandling<Person> died in the same year, both having perfected a brand of hilariously neurotic comedy fit for a   culture. And this time <Person>Abe Vigoda<Person>, of the “Godfather” movies and “<Person>Barney Miller<Person>,” actually did die, after having not actually done so years ago when wildly uninformed people spread the word that he had. On the other side of the camera were directors whose vision came to us from all parts: <Person>Jacques Rivette<Person>, the French New Wave auteur, with his   meditations on life and art <Person>Abbas Kiarostami<Person>, the Iranian master, with his searching examinations of ordinary lives <Person>Andrzej Wajda<Person>, a rival to <Person>Ingmar Bergman<Person> and <Person>Akira Kurosawa<Person> in some critics’ eyes, with his haunting tales of <Location>Poland<Location> under the boot first of Nazis and then of Communists. A long roster of television stars of a generation or two ago passed on, images of their younger selves frozen in time: <Person>Noel Neill<Person> (“Adventures of Superman”) <Person>Alan Young<Person> (“Mister Ed”) <Person>Robert Vaughn<Person> (“The Man From U. N. C. L. E. ”) <Person>William Schallert<Person> and <Person>Patty Duke<Person> (father and daughter on “The <Person>Patty Duke<Person> Show”) <Person>Dan Haggerty<Person> (“The Life and Times of Grizzly Adams”) <Person>Florence Henderson<Person> (“The Brady Bunch”) and <Person>Alan Thicke<Person> (“Growing Pains”). And <Person>Garry Marshall<Person>, the creative force who practically owned prime time with “Happy Days,” “Mork  Mindy,” “Laverne  Shirley” and more, died at 81. On Broadway, lights were dimmed in memory of <Person>Brian Bedford<Person>, <Person>Tammy Grimes<Person> and <Person>Anne Jackson<Person>, all brilliant in their day. The architect <Person>Zaha Hadid<Person> left behind monuments to her fertile imagination and shaken acolytes around the world. The street photographer <Person>Bill Cunningham<Person>, who found fashion statements on every corner, was suddenly missing, making <Location>Manhattan<Location>, overnight, a less idiosyncratic, less interesting place. That smiling skinny man pedaling his bicycle among the honking cabs in a blue French worker’s jacket with a camera slung around his neck  —   what a picture!  —   had split from the scene. So had seemingly a generation of fellow photographers who had made art in recording the last half of the 20th century: <Person>Ruth Gruber<Person>, <Person>Marc Riboud<Person>, <Person>Louis Stettner<Person> and more. And so had the TV journalists <Person>Morley Safer<Person> and <Person>Gwen Ifill<Person> and the TV commentator <Person>John<Person> McLaughlin, all of whom had tried to make sense of it. Music’s other precincts were emptier without the conductor and revolutionary composer <Person>Pierre Boulez<Person> and the new music soprano <Person>Phyllis Curtin<Person> the jazz artists <Person>Mose Allison<Person>, <Person>Bobby Hutcherson<Person> and <Person>Gato Barbieri<Person> the rapper <Person>Phife Dawg<Person> (<Person>Malik Taylor<Person>) and the Latin megastar <Person>Juan Gabriel<Person>. Silicon Valley saw a giant depart in <Person>Andrew S. Grove<Person>, who led the semiconductor revolution at <Organization>Intel<Organization>. The television industry lost a   executive, <Person>Grant Tinker<Person>, who in the ’80s made <Organization>NBC<Organization> the network to watch in prime time. Astrophysics, and the smaller world of women in science, said farewell to a pioneer and a champion in <Person>Vera Rubin<Person>. And for tens of thousands of people who might have choked to death had they not been saved by his simple but ingenious maneuver, the passing of <Person>Henry J. Heimlich<Person> prompted not just sympathy but, even more, gratitude. Come to think of it, eliciting a large, if silent, thank you from those who live on is not a bad way for anyone to go. Which brings us to <Organization>Marion Pritchard<Organization>. Few who died in 2016 could have inspired measures of gratitude more profound. She was a brave young Dutch student and a   gentile who risked her life to save Jews from death camps in the early 1940s, in one instance shooting a Nazi stooge before he could seize three little children she had been hiding. By her estimate she saved 150 people. How many were still alive when she died a few weeks ago at 96 is anyone’s guess. But we know for certain that some were, and we can reasonably surmise that a good many more were, too, all of them still in possession of her selfless gift and her matchless legacy, their very lives.

title: Kim Jong-un Says North Korea Is Preparing to Test Long-Range Missile - The New York Times
author: Choe Sang-Hun
content: <Location>SEOUL<Location>, <Location>South Korea<Location>  —   <Location><Location>North Korea<Location>’s<Location> leader, <Person>Kim<Person>   said on Sunday that his country was making final preparations to conduct its first test of an intercontinental ballistic missile  —   a bold statement less than a month before the inauguration of   <Person>Donald J. <Person>Trump<Person><Person>. Although <Location>North Korea<Location> has conducted five nuclear tests in the last decade and more than 20 ballistic missile tests in 2016 alone, and although it habitually threatens to attack <Location>the United States<Location> with nuclear weapons, the country has never   an intercontinental ballistic missile, or ICBM. In his annual New Year’s Day speech, which was broadcast on the <Location>North’s<Location>   <Location>KCTV<Location> on Sunday, Mr. <Person>Kim<Person> spoke proudly of the strides he said his country had made in its nuclear weapons and ballistic missile programs. He said <Location>North Korea<Location> would continue to bolster its weapons programs as long as <Location>the United States<Location> remained hostile and continued its joint military exercises with <Location>South Korea<Location>. “We have reached the final stage in preparations to   an intercontinental ballistic rocket,” he said. Analysts in the region have said Mr. <Person>Kim<Person> might conduct another weapons test in coming months, taking advantage of leadership changes in <Location>the United States<Location> and <Location>South Korea<Location>. Mr. <Person>Trump<Person> will be sworn in on Jan. 20. In <Location>South Korea<Location>, President <Person>Park<Person>   whose powers were suspended in a <Location>Parliamentary<Location> impeachment on Dec. 9, is waiting for <Organization>the Constitutional Court<Organization> to rule on whether she should be formally removed from office or reinstated. If <Location>North Korea<Location> conducts a    test in coming months, it will test Mr. <Person>Trump<Person>’s new administration despite years of increasingly harsh sanctions, <Location>North Korea<Location> has been advancing toward Mr. <Person>Kim<Person>’s professed goal of arming his isolated country with the ability to deliver a nuclear warhead to <Location>the United States<Location>. Mr. <Person>Kim<Person>’s speech on Sunday indicated that <Location>North Korea<Location> may   a   rocket several times this year to complete its ICBM program, said <Person>Cheong<Person>   a senior research fellow at <Organization>the Sejong Institute<Organization> in <Location>South Korea<Location>. The first of such tests could come even before Mr. <Person>Trump<Person>’s inauguration, Mr. <Person>Cheong<Person> said. “We need to take note of the fact that this is the first New Year’s speech where <Person>Kim<Person>   mentioned an intercontinental ballistic missile,” he said. In his speech, Mr. <Person>Kim<Person> did not comment on Mr. <Person>Trump<Person>’s election. Doubt still runs deep that <Location>North Korea<Location> has mastered all the technology needed to build a reliable ICBM. But analysts in the region said the <Location>North’s<Location> launchings of   rockets to put satellites into orbit in recent years showed that the country had cleared some key technological hurdles. After the <Location>North’s<Location> satellite launch in February, <Location>South Korea<Location>n defense officials said the <Organization>Unha<Organization> rocket used in the launch, if successfully reconfigured as a missile, could fly more than 7, 400 miles with a warhead of 1, 100 to 1, 300 pounds  —   far enough to reach most of <Location>the United States<Location>. <Location>North Korea<Location> has deployed Rodong ballistic missiles that can reach most of <Location>South Korea<Location> and <Location>Japan<Location>, but it has had a spotty record in   the <Organization>Musudan<Organization>, its   ballistic missile with a range long enough to reach American military bases in the Pacific, including those on <Location>Guam<Location>. The North has also claimed a series of successes in testing various ICBM technologies, although its claims cannot be verified and are often disputed by officials and analysts in the region. It has said it could now make nuclear warheads small enough to fit onto a ballistic missile. It also claimed success in testing the   technology that allows a   missile to return to the Earth’s atmosphere without breaking up. In April, <Location>North Korea<Location> reported the successful ground test of an engine for an intercontinental ballistic missile. At the time, Mr. <Person>Kim<Person> said the North “can tip   intercontinental ballistic rockets with more powerful nuclear warheads and keep any cesspool of evils in the Earth, including the U. S. mainland, within our striking range. ” On Sept. 9, the North conducted its fifth, and most powerful, nuclear test. Mr. <Person>Kim<Person> later attended another ground test of a new   rocket engine, exhorting his government to prepare for another rocket launch as soon as possible. title: Sick With a Cold, Queen Elizabeth Misses New Year’s Service - The New York Times
